1g0ZVK2KLi55p7nyF54s.cover: What are the basic operations on linked lists?
1g0ZVK2KLi55p7nyF54s.content:
1. Initialize the list.
2. Determine whether the list is empty.
3. Print the list.
4. Find the length of the list.
5. Destroy the list.
6. Retrieve the value contained in the first node.
7. Retrieve the value contained in the last node.
8. Search the list for a given item.
9. Insert an item in the list.
10. Delete an item from the list.
11. Make a copy of the linked list.

2q2zz5djQy1NrxpFYonc.content: A linked list is a set of dynamically allocated nodes, arranged in such a way that each node contains one value and one pointer; The pointer always points to the next member of the list, if the pointer is NULL or ZERO then it is the last node in the list.

BJMpqTOU5ER6QcSq9VjY.cover: What are the basic operations on array?
BJMpqTOU5ER6QcSq9VjY.content:
1. Initializing the array.
2. Clear or Destroy the array.
3. Determine whether the array is empty.
4. Determine whether the array is full.
5. Find the size of the array. (how many items the array is holding)
6. Search for an item in the array.
7. Insert an item in the array.
8. Replace an item in the array. (by location)
9. Delete an item from the array.
10. Get/Access an item from a specific location.

CsOfWdRRuHCzOSypFR1M.content: An array is a fixed-size collection of elements of the same data type, stored in contiguous memory locations.

gWSaDWxlLJJX0kKYzwxm.content: An algorithm is a set of well-defined instructions to solve a particular problem.

rAOltnT50pcuBn31ckNg.cover: What are the software life cycle phases?
